div.p: Chairman Warren Kimball called the meeting to order at 9:45 a.m. The classified portion of the minutes of the previous meeting was distributed to the Committee for its approval.

Deputy Assistant Secretary George Kennedy welcomed the Committee on behalf of Assistant Secretary Tutwiler. He said the Department of State takes its commitment to a 30-year line very seriously. PA is making sure the Historian’s Office has all the resources it needs to publish the projected volumes. He expressed PA’s continuing concern with the delay in the declassification of the remaining volumes for the Eisenhower administration. He stated that the logjam has to be broken. PA is ready to take on responsibility for the coordination of declassification provided that it can have the additional resources that would be necessary. He also stressed the need for collective management of the process.
The Committee then approved the minutes of the previous meeting and approved the draft agenda subject to change.

Department of State Historian and Executive Secretary of the Committee William Z. Slany gave his report on the status of the Foreign Relations series that had been sent to Committee members previously. He noted that HO anticipates the publication of 13-14 volumes in FY 1992, exceeding its goal, and foresees publication of another dozen volumes in FY 1993, including most of the remaining Eisenhower administration volumes. The PA Bureau has made every effort to provide the necessary funding for publication, including the transfer of resources within PA.

Kimball pointed out that at this rate of publication, the series will not reach the 30-year line for 5 years; the 3-5 years permitted by the legislation seems to have slipped to 5 years. He questioned whether the Committee should call attention to this. Anna Nelson suggested discussing this at the Friday afternoon session. Bradford Perkins suggested that the Committee might want to look at some volumes that had been in declassification an inordinately long time. It was agreed to discuss this suggestion later.

Slany stated that HO is pursuing the matter of access with various agencies but was encountering some problems. HO still has no memorandum of agreement with the Department of Defense. HO historians have had no problem gaining access to the Department of Defense documents, but we need a memorandum of agreement to ensure Committee members’ access to documents. The Committee expressed concern with this and noted that it might want to see some Department of Defense records. NSA did not sign the draft memorandum of understanding that was given to it, stating that they thought it was unnecessary. Kimball will write a letter to Slany stating the Committee’s concern.

Slany gave the Committee members copies of a letter from CIA Historian Ken McDonald that indicated he had assigned staff members to collect CIA records concerning the 1953 coup in Iran. These documents would be submitted for declassification review to CIA’s Center for the Study of Intelligence. McDonald stated that CIA had no backlog of CIA records in processing for State historians and no pending requests from State historians for access to CIA records.

Slany said that HO had held up its requests for access at McDonald’s request. Kimball, noting that the Committee had expressed interest in Guatemala as well as Iran, stated that the Committee had merely asked for a plan on how to deal with this issue. The Committee authorized him to make a written request for such a plan. Emily Rosenberg asked if the part of McDonald’s letter about a search through CIA files for documents on Guatemala and Iran could be made public. Slany will take this up with McDonald and noted that CIA was to look at the question of how the material could best be released, whether in a Foreign Relations volume, publication by CIA, or through releasing the documents to NARA with a finding aid. Rosenberg asked about a target date for this.

Slany said the question of how CIA would deal with Foreign Relations declassification was still being worked out. It was intended that the new unit under David Grease would be responsible for declassification, but as yet there has been no transfer of responsibility. The declassification staff is now preoccupied with the question of Kennedy assassination documents. He asked Joe Chaddic, Chief of HDR, to comment. Chaddic stated that for the first time in his experience, both CIA and NSC have completed all their taskings.

There was discussion of publication of material concerning the activities of the Committee. Kimball thought an annual report would be enough. The question was raised whether there should be one single report or whether members should report separately to the organizations they represent, with Nelson and Jane Picker noting that the organizations have different interests. Kimball expressed concern that Committee members might seem to be contradicting each other; he thought the Committee should speak with one voice. Picker noted that some sessions are open to the public. Perkins asked that this subject be discussed later. Slany pointed out that the Committee is required to make two annual reports, one unclassified.

Slany raised the question of making the Committee’s public documents accessible to the public as the law requires. George Chalou of NARA pointed out that the Committee records are part of the Department of State records, but the State Department Library and the FOI reading room both require a building pass. Nelson pointed out that the NARA library is accessible to the
public. The Committee asked Slany to investigate this and report at the next meeting.
The meeting adjourned at 10:30 a.m. for a break.
The Committee reconvened at 11 a.m. Slany addressed several questions the Committee had raised at the May meeting:

item.p: 1. The Committee inquired about declassification of records older than 30 years. Slany had no answer for the Committee on this issue but Rosenberg said she would discuss this in the report of her subcommittee.

2. The Committee asked for establishment of the principle that record blocks be declassified when the oldest documents were 30 years old, in order to be in compliance with the law. Slany indicated that he would check with the Department’s Legal Office.

3. The Committee asked for information on the status of the 1958-1960 Indonesia compilation of Foreign Relations. It was decided that David Mabon, the concerned Division chief, would report to the Committee the next day. [Subsequently, the Committee did not have time to hear this report.]

div.p: Jeanne Pryor, who manages Foreign Relations declassification in FPC/HDR, was introduced to the Committee. She handed out a composite report of where each volume was in the declassification process, indicating that she had prepared it as a management tool to help her get a handle on her new job. It was not a duplicate of HO’s chart because it had more as well as different information. She described it as a snapshot of the process at this time. Glenn LaFantasie noted that it served as an interbureau managerial “checks and balances” system.
In response to a question, Pryor explained that “verification” was a joint HO-HDR review of excisions and deletions in a volume prior to sending declassified manuscript out to the printer.

Nelson asked about the Cuba volumes for 1961-1963, which seemed to be an anomaly. Pryor responded that Cuba Vol. XI was not a normal volume as tentative selections had been submitted to HDR prior to HO’s completion of the manuscript.
Nelson asked if HDR reviewed HO’s annotation and was told that it did.
As to questions from the Committee on Pryor’s memorandum about Japan and Indonesia, LaFantasie responded that these volumes would be discussed tomorrow.

In introducing the subcommittee report on the planning of the Johnson administration volumes, Slany noted that State Department historian David Patterson had been at the Kennedy Library the previous week. This was HO’s last trip to that Library. An archivist technician had been working at the Johnson Library in Austin in preparation for HO, and we were ready to begin research and compilation on the Johnson era volumes. Patterson would be working there this autumn.

Nelson reported on behalf of the subcommittee which also included Arnold Taylor. She explained that they could not review a 1964-1968 volume as none had been compiled or annotated. Instead, they discussed with LaFantasie China, 1961-1963, to review the scope of the Johnson volumes.

The gist of the subcommittee’s report was that the same type of annotation should be retained, including footnotes summarizing other documents, but that the summaries could be shortened. The subcommittee could not agree with the assumption that summaries of documents or attachments to documents could not be included because the documents would eventually be at the National Archives. This precipitated a lengthy discussion of NARA’s treatment of Department of State lot files.

Kimball said he understood that NARA “broke up” lot files. Mabon pointed out that they were often “consolidated” or combined before they ever got to Archives. David Langbart and Chalou explained that the Department of State screens and consolidates certain lot files under guidelines established in the 1960s:

item.p: 1) Some special collections, records of high officials, and other NARA designated files are not broken up.
2) Other lot files, however, are broken up or even destroyed. The citing of a single document in a Foreign Relations volume does not mean that the lot file will be accessioned.

3) Lot files were screened (i.e., duplicates destroyed and some documents moved to the Central Files) by State Department records personnel. Langbart indicated that the policy is to make the Central Files as comprehensive as possible since they are indexed.

div.p:
Chalou said the essential point was that NARA could not control what other agencies did with their records before they were transferred to NARA. Asked by Kennedy if the screening
process needs to be reviewed, Langbart said in his opinion it does. The Committee members thought that a subcommittee possibly headed by Ann Van Camp could examine the issue.

Kimball returned to the question of the nature of annotation in the Foreign Relations volumes, pointing out that the issue should be resolved, because the compilers needed guidance for the Johnson administration volumes. Nelson reiterated that although the present summaries in footnotes were too long, some summaries were necessary because the document might not be preserved in the Archives. Perkins disagreed, contending that the important thing was to get the volumes published promptly. As far as he was concerned, the volumes could have no notes at all; the Foreign Relations series was not a substitute for the National Archives. Either a document was worthy of being printed or it wasn’t, but the publication process had to be kept rolling. Betty Glad argued that speed was not as important as thoroughness.

Glad also asked why 800 pages was the number settled upon ‘ for the Johnson volumes. Kimball said total pages, not the number of pages per volume, was the important figure. Slany interjected that large volumes would impact adversely on public access at Presidential libraries. LaFantasie stated that the target of 800 pages was flexible, and an issue for negotiation among himself, the compiler, and the division chief. As for 800-page volumes, economy was a factor, but processing difficulties were crucial. The longer a volume, the more time and money was needed to declassify, print, proofread, index, and publish it.

Glad suggested that increased selectivity required more time rather than less. Kimball hoped that adjustments would be made rather than compressing key issues into 800-page volumes and expanding less important ones to fill 800 pages. LaFantasie again stressed his flexibility, but noted that when page limitations exceed their targets without negotiation, there were big problems.
The Committee adjourned for lunch at noon.
The meeting reconvened at 1:45 p.m.
Kimball asked for the “professional comments” of the compilers on the proposed changes in annotation for the LBJ volumes.

Mabon stated that he questioned the assumptions that the volumes are exclusively for people who will work at the National Archives. The series has a larger audience and objective: to provide a representative record of U.S. policy.

Harriet Schwar noted that reduced coverage and greater selectivity required that footnotes provide continuity. She added that careful use of footnotes avoided some declassification problems and sometimes got the sense of a document published.

Nina Noring stated that the coverage in Foreign Relations had to be coherent and clear and that annotation bridged the gaps in coverage. To keep this under control, she suggested the use of specific limits on the size of footnotes, such as restrictions on the number of lines, because it required the compiler to be more concise and careful.
Paul Claussen also pointed to the non-scholarly audience and the need for adequate coverage.
Charles Sampson, describing himself as a “minimalist,” noted that the proliferation of documents in the Johnson period would require very careful annotation procedures.
Ted Keefer doubted that the Johnson era could be covered in the currently planned 33 volumes and stressed the need for more personnel as well as retaining experienced personnel.

Slany reported that HO currently had two vacancies. One would be filled as of September, and the process for filling the other was going forward right now. LaFantasie doubted that more volumes or more personnel would produce more documentation because of the realities involved in the declassification and publication process -- only so much material can pass through the pipeline at any one time. Kennedy added that the Department was fully behind HO and was working full speed to fill its empty positions.

Kimball indicated that the Committee was pleased to know that the Department was acting expeditiously to fill vacancies. Kimball then suggested and the Committee agreed to pass on to other business, reserving these matters for a later session.

Nelson began the report of the subcommittee on declassification guidelines (Nelson/Rosenberg), reporting on her observations of the NARA declassification operation. She noted that the staff turnover was constant and that NARA does not sanitize documents but only withholds them in accordance with guidelines provided by the State Department. Her conclusions were that many documents were being withheld or slowed in release by intelligence sources or foreign government information issues rather than because of their content. She did not feel that guidelines were wrongly applied but rather too widely applied.

Rosenberg began her remarks by stating the goals of the subcommittee: 1) to investigate whether current document declassification guidelines would permit the Department of State to meet the publication deadlines established by law for the Foreign Relations series, and 2) to ascertain whether the declassification process has evolved to meet public and scholarly needs after the Cold War’s end.
On both counts, she said, the subcommittee was pessimistic.
Rosenberg distinguished between two types of declassification: that related to the Foreign Relations series and the aggregate declassification of all State Department records.

Concerning Foreign Relations, the subcommittee was pleased with the declassification goals being set and some of the efforts made to attain those goals. Rosenberg noted with approval the appointment of Pryor at HDR as deputy in charge, of coordinating the Foreign Relations declassification effort. She also noted that the review process in other agencies shows signs of becoming more efficient. She noted with approval that HDR was now preparing status charts like those of HO. But, she concluded, many bottlenecks still exist which hinder the declassification process and may prevent HO from meeting the publication timeline.

Rosenberg said there have been dramatic improvements and structural changes in the aggregate declassification process. She noted the designation of William Hamilton to coordinate aggregate declassification for HDR and the rapid creation of new aggregate declassification guidelines. She praised the flexibility of these new guidelines (established for 1960-1963) and HDR’s new policy decision that not only will these supersede the old ones but will be retroactive and apply to the earlier record groups. She noted, however, that there will be some delay in the implementation of the new guidelines and the new policy of retroactivity.

There was a discussion of whether the new, less restrictive giudelines would have an impact on FOIA requests. Chaddic assured the Committee that although FOIA requests for State documents at NARA might be referred to State under the old guidelines, they would be reviewed at the State Department using current guidelines. Underscored text is HDR revision. The delay would not be a long one. Finally, Rosenberg reported that steps were being taken to make the computerized information retrieval and database systems of the State Department (INFORM) and NARA compatible. There is already a link between INFORM and the database at the Carter Presidential Library, she said.
Rosenberg turned next to a. discussion of the various declassification bottlenecks which may hamper work on the Foreign Relations series and the work of diplomatic historians generally.

Despite the efforts to improve the compatibility of documentary databases she had just outlined, Rosenberg concluded that the incompatibility and fragmentation of scholarly information management systems remains a serious obstacle to historical research. She stressed the need for more interlocking databases to improve user efficiency and suggested that the Committee work officially to improve information management coordination. Of particular use in a database, she said, would be information concerning documents withheld from release. She said there were actually surprisingly few such documents.

Rosenberg was hopeful that the NARA declassification database might make an unusually helpful aid to scholars attempting to do research in Department of State files. Langbart pointed out that the CIA regards the NARA database as classified. Rosenberg expressed a wish to find a way to make the system available to the public.

Rosenberg noted the large number of people involved in the declassification process and the overlapping tasks they perform. It is a personnel-intensive process, she said. This had always been the case and may not be a bad thing. She suggested that it may be time for a review of this system. Perhaps there is a different optimal mix of reviewers (archival technicians and HDR personnel) for different types of documents which would improve the efficiency of the review process. Nelson concurred with Rosenberg that the Committee should recommend that an optimal mix be explored with an eye toward improving the efficiency of the review process.

Finally, Rosenberg said that the category of “foreign government information” which is often not declassified, is defined too broadly and too vaguely by the declassifiers. There is an over-emphasis on what constitutes foreign government information, she said. The Committee should recommend narrowing the definition of this information or at least re-examining it.

There followed a discussion between members of the Committee and the HDR staff over the current definition of foreign government information. Chaddic defined it as a foreign government document or information in a U.S. document that is provided by a foreign government. Nelson and Chaddic reviewed the considerations that required Soviet press
clippings to be regarded as foreign government information, though not classified.*

In response to a question from Kimball/- Chaddic explained that the contents of a memorandum of conversation between an American official and an official of a foreign government would be considered foreign government information and might remain classified depending on its contents. It would be a judgment call. Many such decisions concerning foreign government information are judgment calls requiring HDR participation. Underscored text is HDR revision.

Chaddic said that a call for a re-examination of what constitutes foreign government information would not be helpful to HDR because such a re-examination was already underway. He asked for specific recommendations from the Committee. Otherwise, he said, he might have to call in outside management consultants for advice.

Rosenberg was concerned that the Department could not meet its obligation under the new law to open records at 30 years. The Department would have to “play catch-up” in accelerating the process. The Department had acknowledged the need by deciding to perform declassification review in State on some specialized issues like a UN lot file or Berlin, rather than giving it to NARA. But major problems remained such as the fragmented management of information and overlappping tasks of declassification reviewers at NARA and the State Department. The program needed re-examination.

Chaddic commended the subcommittee’s assistance but asked again for more specific help from the Committee. He has been re-examining and revising the declassification process for months. He doesn’t need Underscored text is HDR revision. a recommendation now simply to re-examine the problem.

Another discussion ensued about the efficiency of the current mix of personnel involved in the aggregate declassification process. Hamilton of HDR concurred with a point made earlier by Nelson that many archival personnel involved in the initial stages of the process are young, inexperienced technicians who are lulled into occasional lapses by the drudgery of the task. He maintained that because of mistakes made by the NARA reviewers, it was necessary for State Department reviewers from HDR to scan their work, sometimes check over it very thoroughly. He said that the HDR review by experienced hands was necessary to the aggregate declassification process to validate or lift proposed denials and to check for errors by the NARA reviewers.*

Hamilton and Committee members reviewed further the number of reviews and the reasons for them. First review was by low-ranking archives technicians at NARA. A NARA team leader made a second review when he reviewed the technicians’ decisions. A third review occurred when State/HDR re-reviewed NARA’s reviews. ‘Then HDR, lacking full confidence in NARA’s junior technicians, often reviewed all of a box of records to check behind NARA. HDR’s comment on this paragraph reads: “The third sentence as written is what was said, but is factually incorrect; team leaders do not perform the second review. (SIC) Technicians’ decisions are checked by a second NARA reviewer. A third review occurred when State/HDR validated NARA’s reviews. Sometimes, all classified documents in a box of records are checked, though not on a line-by-line basis as during NARA’s reviews.”
Kimball took issue rather strongly with the idea that this many-layered review was the most efficient way of declassifying documents. He adjourned the meeting for a break.

Following the break, the Committee continued to consider the report of the subcommittee on declassification guidelines. Kimball proposed that someone of authority at the National Archives, namely the Archivist Don Wilson, be invited to meet with the Committee to discuss several of the items raised in the discussion of the subcommittee report. After some discussion, it was decided that Kimball should telephone Wilson to extend an invitation to meet with the Committee the following day and that if Wilson could not attend then no one lower than Trudy Peterson’s level be sent. Kimball then left the room to make the telephone call, leaving Rosenberg to chair the discussion in his absence.

Perkins asked why NARA needed guidelines once the declassification review had been completed for a given record block. Chaddic explained that once the Department’s records were transferred to NARA, NARA had responsibility for responding to FOIA and mandatory review requests. For the same reason, guidelines were also passed on to the Presidential libraries. The guidelines contained two lists for each subject. One described issues that were no longer sensitive and that could be released without consulting the Department. The other described matters that remained sensitive and were to be referred to the Department of State for decision. A problem could arise because NARA might not have the most recent guidelines for a given subject that were more liberal than previous guidelines. In this case, once the document was
referred to the Department of State the more liberal guidelines were applied leading to the release of the information.

The Committee then focused on the guidelines for Yugoslavia. Nelson raised the point that those concerned with protecting security information had far less to worry about with the release of large blocks of documents that were 30 years old than they did with information released under FOIA and mandatory review. If one or two mistakes were made in the review of 30-year old documents (and sensitive information inadvertently released) it would take a considerable amount of time for a private researcher to locate the offending items and even then it was highly unlikely that the discovery would be publicized in the popular press as very few journalists did this kind of research. In contrast, a number of journalists used FOIA and publicized their findings.

Glad referred to a statement made prior to the break by Hamilton that demonstrated a concern that inadvertent release of sensitive information might, as in past instances, damage relations with foreign governments. Underscored text is HDR revision. She felt that this sentiment was not in accord with the mandate under the new legislation. She pointed out that just because a foreign government might protest an item did not mean that release damaged the national security of the united States. She did not think that the potential objection of a foreign government should be a major concern. Glad said that a question of values was involved. Why did the Department appear to be more sensitive to foreign government criticism than it was to potential criticism from the U.S. Congress. Also, a different standard was being used here than was applied to some other government activities. Many potential regulations by OSHA and EPA were not issued because they would cost too much. Here any cost seemed bearable to withhold certain information from the American people. A cost-effective argument should also be applied in this area. She called this a “fundamental value conflict.”

Rosenberg then raised two points. First, the subcommittee had been impressed with Department of State efforts in this area, but this attitude needs to spread. She noted that the public expected change in the wake of the Cold War. Secondly, there was a widespread view that the legislation would be difficult to meet. The Committee was supposed to be an early-warning system for such problems, to call attention to this fact and find ways to bridge the gap. The Committee should urge even more effective coordination among HO, HDR, and NARA. It can project what kind of resources are needed and it can recommend efficiencies to eliminate duplication of effort. Rosenberg said that she and Nelson felt that much progress had
been made but there were roadblocks that had to be overcome to get the job done. She thought the solution to bridge the gap and meet the legislation would be a combination of increased resources, that is money, and of introducing efficiencies into the process.

Nelson emphasized the need for rethinking declassification as an artifact of the Cold War. If the United States set out deliberately to construct the most expensive system possible to retain secrets, it could not have created a more costly system than the one it had now. The danger of the Cold War was past and it was time to move on.

Taylor asked whether there were any U.S. bilateral agreements with foreign governments pertaining to the need to protect foreign government information. Chaddic said he knew of none, but that protecting foreign government information on a reciprocal basis came down to our own self interest. The decision to withhold such information was made on a case-by-case basis in consultation with Underscored text is HDR revision. the relevant geographic bureau and desk.

Kimball returned to the room and said that Trudy Peterson had agreed to come at 10:30 a.m. the following day. The Committee would want to speak with her about coordination between the State Department and NARA and about foreign government information. Perkins objected that NARA had no control over the withholding of foreign government information. Kimball explained that they would ask how the Archives uses the definition of foreign government information supplied by the Deparmtent of State.

Kimball then proposed that instead of continuing the discussion on declassification guidelines that the Committee focus instead on the Cuba agenda item that was scheduled for 10:45 on Friday. He said that they could not discuss Japan at this moment because the Japan desk officer was not present.

Kimball wished it written into the minutes his explanation of why “Comments from Staff” appeared in the agenda for this meeting and would reappear in subsequent agenda. He said that this was a reminder to the HO staff that the Committee would discuss with them any declassification and compilation issues that the staff might wish to raise. None had been raised for this meeting so the Committee could pass over this agenda item.

Kimball then asked Slany to give his presentation on the preparation of two volumes on Cuba for the 1961-1963 triennium. Slany said that the Cuba experience was a model and a unique opportunity to show what could be done. The volumes
had special and unique problems of declassification and compilation. Because of the public attention being given the release of the U.S.-Soviet correspondence over the missile crisis, the Office determined to try to accelerate the compilation process of the Cuba volumes, in part to test the system: whether State historians could have access to CIA documents and whether HO and HDR could cooperate. He also noted that this was a test of the framework of the legislation. He then turned the presentation over to LaFantasie.

LaFantasie said that public anticipation arising out of the release of the Kennedy-Khrushchev correspondence on the Cuban missile crisis had created a foundation for what the Office wanted to do with the two Cuba volumes. This experiment had been largely successful, but some difficulties had also been encountered. One success was access to CIA documents; the compiler had been able to consult documents relating to Cuba and order photocopies. These photocopies had been received, although only after a long delay. Human factors, however, intervened. The main compiler, Louis Smith, had a serious illness that took him out of the office for a substantial amount of time. Charles Sampson and Edward Keefer were reassigned from other volumes to work on Cuba. Documentation from CIA did not arrive until the eleventh hour and was integrated into the second Cuba volume that covered the missile crisis.

HO also received a high degree of cooperation from HDR which agreed to accept and review documents that had not yet been edited and annotated, a departure from normal procedure. (It was a matter of concern to the reviewer that, having agreed to a departure from HDR’s regular practice, he was not receiving documents to review. Underscored text is HDR revision.) Keefer and Sampson then completed and submitted an annotated manuscript to HDR. The annotated manuscript is now going through clearance, although only the annotation is being reviewed. LaFantasie admitted that although the process had been expedited, the project was still off schedule, behind by 2-1/2 to 3 months. The goal had been to publish these volumes by the spring of 1993, and this was still possible if “spring” were defined loosely. He admitted that this had become a complicated and complex project.

LaFantasie said that Cuba I (1961-63, vol. X) was now with other agencies for clearance. Meanwhile, additional documents were being incorporated into the manuscript by the compilers. It would appear that Cuba II (1961-63, vol. XI) was now ahead of Cuba I in the declassification process and would come out
first rather than the two coming out at the same time as originally planned. LaFantasie said he could not declare the experiment a successful one until the bound books had arrived. But he said that this experiment showed that it was possible to accelerate and expedite a volume and it forged a better relationship between HO and HDR. The real test would come, however, in the declassification process when it is revealed how much -- or how little -- the CIA and State are willing to make public.

Slany interjected that LaFantasie was “too cautious.” Great flexibility has been shown by all including CIA. The Office received very revealing documents from CIA that have been included in the volume. The experience also showed how people in our Office can take up the slack caused by unexpected illnesses and interruptions of the schedule.

In response to a question on how the declassification was going, Pryor responded that on April 30 when the compilation and accompanying diskette were submitted, a computer check against the Department’s INFORM System yielded a large number of “hits.” Many of the documents had been the subject of long litigation that resulted in a recent court decision. The HDR reviewer was doing a side-by-side comparison of the results of the court decision and documents in the volume that would facilitate the speedy processing of this volume.

George Herring pointed out that when these volumes appeared, people would not be focusing on the Bay of Pigs or on the Missile Crisis, but on Mongoose. Coverage of Mongoose would be the test of how the volumes would be received.

LaFantasie volunteered that HO had obtained a good deal of material on Mongoose. Pryor confirmed that a number of Mongoose documents had been in the compilation submitted and and were part of the recent court case. Kimball asked whether the litigation would provide leverage for future appeals. Pryor said that it would. During subsequent discussion, it was clarified that the suit had been brought by the National Security Archive and that the decision handed down was narrow in that it applied only to the documents at issue and did not apply to CIA documents on other subjects.

Kimball then directed the discussion to five items that the most recent Foreign Relations Production Status and Projections Chart indicated were behind schedule. Subsequent discussion clarified these items as follows:

item.p: 1) The Intelligence Supplement: HDR explained that the delay was due to the fact that HO submitted the manuscript late and that it was quite large. Chaddic commended the reviewer handling the project for doing “yeoman service.”

2) Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, III, National Security Affairs: HDR explained that it is with other agencies for review. Chaddic drew attention to the status report presented on page 3 of Pryor’s report handed out to the Committee earlier in the session.

3) Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, XII, Near East: Attention was again drawn to Pryor‘s report which indicated that CIA had signed off on the documents in question on July 5 and that verification was awaiting Herschler’s return from vacation.
4-5) Foreign Relations, 1958-1960, Western Europe and Berlin Crisis. It was confirmed that these had now been cleared.

div.p: Perkins pointed out that even though these last two volumes were now nearing completion the length of time that they were in clearance was a matter worth exploring. He noted that the Committee had no current volume it was reviewing and suggested that they might look at one of these at the next meeting. Rosenberg noted that Slany ought to be given the opportunity to suggest a new volume to examine.

The discussion then turned to the proposed preface to the 1958-1960 Japan volume. Kimball indicated that all members of the Committee had liked what Slany had sent to them except for the final paragraph which dealt with the Committee’s role. He then read the text of an alternate paragraph that Perkins had drafted and opened the matter for discussion.

Glad noted that the Committee did make the recommendation that the Japan volume not be published and that this should be recorded in the preface. Perkins indicated his desire that a paragraph be used in all Foreign Relations volumes to indicate which volumes the Committee did or did not review. He did not wish the Committee to be identified with volumes it had not seen, in case some criticism was made of them in later years. Kimball reminded the Committee that in the case of the Japan volume the Committee felt there was a distortion but enough remained of the volume that it deserved publication.

Rosenberg indicated her opposition to drafting different prefaces for each volume the Committee reviewed. Nelson asked Rosenberg whether she would accept language that merely stated whether or not a volume had been reviewed, to which Rosenberg replied no. She preferred a boilerplate that could be used for all volumes and did not wish it to indicate which volumes the Committee reviewed or did not review, because the Committee could not be responsible for possible documents that might be added at a later time.

Kimball explained that he and Perkins were talking about a paragraph dealing with the role of the Advisory Committee. Slany suggested using language from the legislation stating that the Historian was supposed to inform the Committee about declassification problems if they resulted in a manuscript that distorted the historical record. Picker said that the language used needed to reflect that.

Subsequent discussion then focused on what the legislation actually said as to who was to take the initiative in proposing that the Committee review specific volumes and to what extent the Committee was responsible for the integrity of the entire series. After consulting the legislation, it was determined that the Historian had the initiative to select specific volumes for review under Section 403, but Kimball noted that the statute intended the Committee to have responsibility for the entire series by requiring it to oversee procedures. Glad pointed out that there was a concern that the Committee not be seen to have reviewed all volumes.

Perkins indicated his support for Picker’s proposal, indicating that it would get the Committee “off the hook” and might be better than what he proposed. Rosenberg also voiced support for the proposal to use the language from the statute, because it would then be clear when the Committee was not being alerted. She said she was troubled with Kimball’s broad interpretation of the legislation as to the Committee’s responsibility. Picker noted that it would be historically interesting for users to see which volumes the Committee had reviewed. Rosenberg agreed with specific language, but she worried that 10 years from now, people would ask why the Committee had not reviewed a specific volume.

Kimball closed the meeting by indicating that he and Slany would work on the language for a new paragraph that would indicate the Committee’s responsibility for the process and its relationship to any incompleteness in the series. He said the matter would be open for discussion the following day.
The Committee adjourned for the day.

Kimball called the meeting to order at 9:30 a.m. Slany introduced Deputy Director of the Office of Japanese Affairs John F. Scott. Scott described the action memorandum from Tutwiler to Rogers regarding Department justification for denial of documents in the Foreign Relations volume on Japan for 1958-1960. The Department is asking Rogers to make decisions on:

item.p: 1) retaining classification on the bulk of documents at issue,
2) concurrence in the statement to be printed in the preface, and
3) approval of the plan to identify the denied documents in the volume.

div.p: The memorandum is in EAP Front Office for approval. David Mabon reported that the Department of Defense had withdrawn its objections to publication of its previously declassified documents. The Committee expressed its satisfaction with this and expressed the hope that this would establish a precedent.
Perkins asked if the Committee had seen the statement and was assured by Kimball that the Committee had and still needed to draft the final paragraph for the preface statement.

It was noted that the Committee had recommended release of the withheld documents. Rogers has the Committee’s recommendation and the memo from Tutwiler will include Underscored text is EAP revision. a detailed explanation of the reasons for withholding. Scott noted that the justifications for denying the documents fell into three main categories and that the EAP-drafted justification grouped the documents by these topics. The Committee requested that the EAP language be made available at the next meeting, to which Scott agreed.

Glad said that the Committee was not dealing with trivial issues and that the Committee should work out procedures for future volumes. Kimball stated that Department officials had indicated that they considered the Committee had acted responsibly in its general handling of the case. Scott seconded this and said that he and the EAP Bureau appreciated the quality of discussions with the Committee. He then left the meeting.

Kimball asked if in the 10 minutes before the next speaker the Committee would like to work over the last paragraph. He then read the draft paragraph, which stated that the Committee had been apprised of the Department’s decision to withhold a
number of documents which it considered to be integral and essential, and had approved publication of the disclaimer in the preceding paragraphs.

Perkins wanted to add a sentence to the preface of every volume as to whether the Committee had played a role with respect to the volume. Rosenberg thought the paragraph as read by Kimball raised more questions than it answered. She proposed a boilerplate paragraph for all volumes, drawing upon the language of the legislation to indicate the committee’s role in general terms. She pointed out that determining language for every volume with which the Committee was involved could be time consuming. Picker stated that it should be possible to have several boilerplate paragraphs with to cover all contingencies.

Kimball proposed that Picker, with her fresh perspective on historical documentation, draft three paragraphs covering all positions. Nelson said that “approved” should be changed to “agreed to” and the entire Committee approved.

At the Committee’s request, Assistant Legal Adviser for Treaty Affairs Robert E. Dalton described the Department’s program of publication of treaties and agreements and the Digest of U.S. Practice in International Law. He reviewed for the Committee the two statutes mandating publication of treaties: 1 USC 112B and 1 USC 113. Two series met this requirement: TIAS (113), which are single published pamphlets of selected treaties, and U.S. Treaties (112B), which are bound volumes by year and include all treaties.

Treaties can be put into two categories : those that require advice and consent from the Senate, of which there are approximately 13 per year, and international agreements, about 413 per year. With the reduced Department budget, L has sought ways to meet the mandate to publish by using computer technology. Treaty publication is far behind, but the new technology is being used to try to eliminate the backlog. He noted that “unperfected” treaties, which never entered into force, are available in a privately published series, Unperfected Treaties of the United States.

Picker asked whether classified treaties or classified annexes to treaties are subject to regular declassification procedures. Dalton replied that no classified treaties have gone to the Senate since 1791, but that some treaties do have classified annexes, which are never published. Picker asked how one would find out about these and Dalton said that an annex or agreement to a treaty may be classified, but the number of these is small. Chaddic stated that such classified material does get into the Central Files, goes to NARA, and is subject to normal declassification procedures.

Picker asked about the Digest of U.S. Practice in International Law in terms of selection of documents for Foreign Relations volumes. Dalton replied that they were totally separate projects, but noted that the Digest included quite a bit of material relating to treaties. He thought if the Digest were discontinued, the Foreign Relations series might want to include more such material. Picker then asked about continued publication of the Digest and Dalton replied that the Department’s Office of the Inspector General had recommended that the Digest be discontinued. L believes that there are good reasons to continue its publication even with resource limitations; no final decision by L has been taken. Dalton mentioned that a group from the Council of Europe is working on a Digest-like publication.

Picker asked if L documents of interest are finding their way to the Central Files. Dalton told her that a broader question--What is the effect of computerization on the kinds of materials that historians want?--was of more concern. He gave an example about E-mail and fax machines and the loss of the’ written record.

Picker asked about agreements made by other agencies or made by the President without referral to the Department of State. Dalton replied that the Case-Zablocki Act required yearly reports to Congress from agencies on the status of international agreements and that the problem was reasonably under control. Glad asked about the situation prior to the Case Act. Langbart noted that such agreements do show up in the records of various agencies.

Picker asked if the L session was unclassified even though the Committee met in executive session. She wanted the minutes to reflect that the session was unclassified so she could present it to the American Society for International Law.
The session ended at 10:30 a.m.

The meeting reconvened at 10:45 a.m. Kimball announced that the briefing by the Government Printing Officials would be postponed until the November meeting. During a brief discussion about scheduling the next meeting, Kimball noted that a meeting in November would meet the statutory requirement of four Advisory Committee meetings in the calendar year.

Kimball then introduced Trudy Peterson, Assistant Archivist of the U.S., and Jeanne Schauble, Director of the Records Declassification Division at the National Archives, where
archives technicians perform the first declassification review of State Department records. Peterson and Schauble had come to discuss with the Committee its concerns about the declassification process and the legislative deadline of 30 years.

Peterson began by assuring the Committee that the National Archives was also interested in streamlining the declassification process and avoiding duplication of effort. Concerning establishment of priorities for declassification, the Archives was convening a meeting in October at which users can make their wishes known regarding priorities for the Archives’ declassification effort.

Regarding the larger issue of multi-user databases and lists of declassified and denied documents, the National Archives has been exploring ways to share information among agencies, but there is no consensus among all the agencies that have a stake in the issue. NARA has been working with the Information Security Oversight Office (ISOO) to develop a Statement of Work prior to advertising a contract to examine this issue. The Statement of Work would include two parts:

item.p: 1) The contractor would go to the agencies concerned to try to get a consensus on sharing data and on the kinds of data to be shared. The alternatives for information to be included in a shared database include: a minimum amount of information regarding any one document (from/to information), subject tags that could be searched or sorted on, and an optical system that would include documents on-line. The agencies would consider and agree on the amount of information that would be shared.
2) The contractor would then consider the technical possibilities, cost efficiency, and effectiveness of implementing such a shared database.

div.p: Peterson stressed again the importance to NARA, given its limited resources, not to duplicate effort.

Nelson asked if such a shared listing will happen. Peterson replied that the study will certainly happen; her best hope is that some agencies will agree to participate and a model will be created. She felt that even a partial system is better than none.

Rosenberg asked if the database would be available to researchers in some sanitized form. Peterson indicated that, in order to get maximum participation from agencies, making the database public had not been considered. When Rosenberg asked
if the Committee could help in making the database available, Peterson indicated that letters to Congress might help but State and NARA were not the right places to apply pressure.

Nelson wondered if there had been any changes in the declassification and transfer of CIA records to NARA. Peterson noted that NARA has yet to see a change since Director Gates’ statement that the CIA would declassify its records. Unlike the State Department, the CIA strips all classified material from its records before transferring them.

Perkins asked about the relationship between the Department declassification staff (HDR) and NARA and the duplication of effort. Kimball emphasized that the Committee wanted to recommend ways to make the process more efficient and eliminate bottlenecks. He noted that at the minimum the material received four reviews: the first at State, two at NARA, and then a final one at State. HDR’s comment on the last sentence of this paragraph reads: “This sentence may represent what was said, but is factually incorrect. (SIC) He noted that the material received three reviews: two by NARA and the final one by State.:

Peterson noted that NARA had no vested interest in this review, and was assisting the declassification by doing the first “rough cut” on State documents. Taylor wondered if a more qualified reviewer at NARA could process the material, eliminating a second NARA review. Peterson pointed out that the archives technicians positions have been classified at a GS-7 grade level and cannot be upgraded because they only apply guidelines. She said that an interim review by NARA had looked at whether the second review could be eliminated and had concluded that it could not because Underscored text is NARA revision. the second review by NARA archivist catches errors. If State wants to assume that review function, as Perkins suggested, then it could.

Committee members asked several questions about the second review of State documents: what kind of errors does the second review catch, what is the volume of errors. Schauble noted that the second review, which is also a training tool for teaching new employees, picks up errors on both sides — both release and deny. Peterson pointed out that it depends on the reviewers and the complexity of the documents. She repeated that NARA could stop the second review at the risk of deteriorating relations between NARA and the State Department.

In response to questions from Rosenberg and Picker, Schauble noted that the junior archives technicians are trained to be consistent in applying the declassification guidelines to
the documents. Documents are not reviewed differently depending on their classification. At this time, the staff is fully trained, but the turnover in personnel is high, and she is not willing to risk releasing material that should be withheld, especially given the importance of State records.

Kimball asked Peterson about rotating people among several jobs to mitigate the problem of boredom and inattention. Peterson replied that it is possible, but the two problems of training and obtaining clearances for a larger pool of people are formidable.

Glad wondered if the balance always tipped toward continued classification. Peterson stressed that NARA must minimize security violations so that it will keep the confidence of the government’s agencies and continue to receive all agencies’ records. Security violations were formally reported both to the agency and to ISOO and any security violation could make an agency reluctant to cooperate. The system had to be kept as honest as possible, and NABA is cautious in applying declassification guidelines in Underscored text is NARA revision. order to retain the trust of agencies.

Glad asked whether NARA did sampling as a basis for bulk declassification. Peterson indicated that NARA does do sampling and bulk declassification, particularly if a body of records was old and non-sensitive.

Perkins wondered if it were true that NARA does not know if documents have been printed in the Foreign Relations series. Peterson agreed but reminded him that it’s not always clear if all copies of documents are identical.
Kimball asked for recommendations for ways to attack the declassification review problem at NARA. In response, Peterson listed three changes she believes would speed the process:

item.p: 1) The U.S. Government must have a date by which everything would be declassified — a “drop-dead date.”

2) The U.S. Government must have a better definition of foreign government information and a streamlined process for reviewing foreign government information more than 50 years old. These documents should all be referred to the Department of State instead of to the “agencies of interest.”

3) The National Archives needs real declassification guidance from other agencies. State is the only agency that furnishes the most comprehensive guidelines for release and other agencies should emulate this model.*

div.p: Taylor asked about the issue of successor states when considering foreign government information. Chaddic indicated that HDR develops guidelines.

Kimball asked Peterson if there were a way to improve the State guidelines. Peterson indicated that NARA needs comprehensive guidelines that cover all conceivable subjects. New guidelines should indicate that they supersede all previous ones and that they should apply to previous record blocks.
Kimball turned to Chaddic and asked if he could make a public statement that any new guidelines would supersede old ones. Chaddic agreed.

Taylor asked if State declassifiers could be detailed to NARA for one-step declassification. Chaddic noted that cost would be a significant impediment to this, and Schauble added that NARA must review and apply guidelines to documents from other agencies that might appear in State files. Peterson was willing to consider such details.

William Hamilton of HDR noted that he believed that the two-tier system of review worked best because it took advantage of the archival experience in NARA. Kimball again voiced his concern at meeting the legislative deadlines given the many and time-consuming reviews of State documents transferred to NARA.

Nelson was also concerned at the time lag between the physical transfer of records (and their inaccessibility to researchers) and the receipt of new guidelines from State. Langbart explained the process: the records are physically transferred to NARA with draft guidelines, archives technicians review the documents and tab documents for denial, State reviews and finalizes the guidelines; the records are legally accessioned by NARA. Until the guidelines are finalized by State, they cannot be applied by NARA to other accessioned records. Chaddic indicated that the time has been significantly shortened, which Nelson acknowledged, but he insisted that the guidelines have to be reviewed on the basis of experience before they are applied by NARA and Presidential Library personnel to older records. Underscored text is HDR revision.

Nelson commented that the Committee has made several suggestions to accelerate the declassification process in order to meet the statute but all have dismissed as impossible. It appeared to her that it would be impossible to meet the statutory requirement of review and declassification of records at 30 years. Kimball agreed, noting that it seemed as though the Department of State would not be able to meet certain provisions of the law.
At this point, the Committee adjourned for lunch where they would be joined by Under Secretary Rogers.

head.hi: Luncheon Discussion With Under Secretary Rogers, July 24

div.p: Under Secretary John F.W. Rogers told the Committee that he had commissioned a report on reforming the Department’s declassification process, and that he would discuss it soon with Assistant Secretary Tutwiler. The report recommended that the coordination of the declassification process for Foreign Relations volumes, along with the necessary resources to do the job, be shifted to the Historian’s Office.

The Committee expressed its concerns about the redundancies and delays it had identified in the current procedures for the systematic declassification of Department records. Rogers agreed to look into three areas of concern:

item.p: 1) the mixture of annuitants and full-time personnel engaged in the systematic declassification process;
2) the overall management of systematic declassification; and
3) the goals and attitudes of those charged with implementing systematic declassification.
